description: First attested from 1827. Back-formation from enthusiasm, from Ancient Greek ἔνθεος (éntheos, “possessed by a god”), from ἐν (en, “in”) + θεός (theós, “god”)

verbs.description: enthuse (third-person singular simple present enthuses, present participle enthusing, simple past and past participle enthused)

examples: 1970,  Julian Huxley,  Memories:a splendid performance, and I was enthusing over it

entries.meaning: (proscribed, sometimes humorous)  To cause (someone) to feel enthusiasm or to be enthusiastic.
examples: The novelty of the film enthused the audience.
